Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: A home loan repayment is due in two months, and the mother needs to prepare for it
Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: An angry client is loudly criticising a cut moments before the salon is due to close.
Story: The clock on the salon wall ticked closer to closing time, but the angry voice in my chair drowned out everything else. My client glared at her reflection, her words sharp and loud enough for the other stylists to glance over. “This isn’t what I asked for! I can’t go out like this!” she snapped. I felt the familiar knot in my stomach tighten. I needed her to leave satisfied, or at least not furious—bad reviews meant fewer clients, and fewer clients meant less money. With the home loan repayment looming in two months, every tip, every appointment mattered. My mind raced with numbers and deadlines, but my heart ached for my son waiting at home, probably already in his pajamas, hoping I’d be there to tuck him in. I wanted to comfort him, to be the mother he needed, but right now, I had to be the professional, calm hairdresser. The weight of both roles pressed down on me as I faced her in the mirror, searching for the right words, torn between my family’s needs and my client’s demands.
